Data.Immigrant Languages: Arabic (54,900), Burushaski, Chinese, Iranian Persian (18,000), Judeo-Iraqi Arabic, Rohingya (40,000), Uyghur, Western Armenian (100)
Data.General References: Bradley 1997, Bradley 2005, Breton 1997, Campbell and King 2011, Hugoniot 1970, Marrison 1967, Masica 1991, Matisoff et al 1996, Singh 1994a, Singh 1994b, Singh 1995a, Singh 1995b, VanBik 2006, Van Driem 2001, Van Driem 2007
Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for India is 460. Of these, 447 are living and 13 are extinct. Of the living languages, 419 are indigenous and 28 are non-indigenous. Furthermore, 64 are institutional, 119 are developing, 138 are vigorous, 112 are in trouble, and 14 are dying.

Only 23 Greater Andamese people from the Aka-Kora, Aka-Cari, and Aka-Jeru tribes remained in 1951 (Van Driem 2001, pp. 215–216).

Spoken Languages.name: Aka-Jeru
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Became extinct in latter 20th century.

Spoken Languages.name: Aka-Kede
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker probably died by 1940 (Van Driem 2001).

Spoken Languages.name: Aka-Kol
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker died in 1921 (Van Driem 2001).

Spoken Languages.name: Aka-Kora
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last speaker, Boro, died in 2009.

Spoken Languages.name: Akar-Bale
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker died by 1940 (Van Driem 2001).

Spoken Languages.name: Nagarchal
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker either died or shifted to Hindi [hin] or Northern Gondi [gno] by 1981 (Ishtiaq 1999).

Spoken Languages.name: Nora
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Had 300 speakers at beginning of 20th century, but extinct by end of century.

Spoken Languages.name: Oko-Juwoi
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker died in 1931 (Van Driem 2001).

Data.Official Name: Independent State of Papua New Guinea
Data.General References: Anceaux 1961, Carrington 1996, Foley 2005, Franklin 1968, Healey 1964, Hooley 1971, Hooley and McElhanon 1970, McElhanon 1970, McElhanon 1978, Pawley 2005, Ross 1988, Ross 2005, Sankoff 1968, Shaw 1973, Shaw 1986, Wurm 2000, Wurm 2007, Wurm and Hattori 1981, Z’Graggen 1971, Z’Graggen 1975
Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for Papua New Guinea is 851. Of these, 840 are living and 11 are extinct. Of the living languages, 839 are indigenous and 1 is non-indigenous. Furthermore, 39 are institutional, 281 are developing, 266 are vigorous, 211 are in trouble, and 43 are dying.

Spoken Languages.name: English
Spoken Languages.data: De facto national language. Used as LWC in the southern part of the country.  3,150,000 in Papua New Guinea, all users. L1 users: 150,000 in Papua New Guinea (Crystal 2003a). L2 users: 3,000,000 (Crystal 2003a).

Spoken Languages.name: Tok Pisin
Spoken Languages.data: De facto national language.  4,122,000 in Papua New Guinea, all users. L1 users: 122,000 in Papua New Guinea (2004 SIL). L2 users: 4,000,000. 50,000 monolinguals. Total users in all countries: 4,125,740 (as L1: 125,740; as L2: 4,000,000).

Spoken Languages.name: Dobu
Spoken Languages.data: Lingua franca in D’Entrecasteaux Islands.  110,000, all users. L1 users: 10,000 (1998 SIL). L2 users: 100,000 (1987 SIL). 6,000 monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Kâte
Spoken Languages.data: Established as a church language by the Lutherans in the early 1900s.  100,000, all users. L1 users: 20,000 (2011 M. Muhujupe). L2 users: 80,000 (1980 UBS).

Spoken Languages.name: Kuanua
Spoken Languages.data: Used as a church language widely in New Ireland and East New Britain provinces within the United Church. It is not used beyond the church domain in most of the language groups that use it for church.  81,000, all users. L1 users: 61,000 (1991 SIL). L2 users: 20,000 (1985 UBS).

Spoken Languages.name: Kuman
Spoken Languages.data: Major area language used as a trade language for all the other Chimbu languages.  115,000 (2000 census), increasing. Few monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Motu, Hiri
Spoken Languages.data: Recognized language (1975, Constitution, Articles 67 and 68). Used long before European contact by participants in the Hiri trade cycle between the Motu people and their neighbors on the south east coast of the island of New Guinea. Since about 1970 the use of Hiri Motu as a lingua franca has been declining in favor of English [eng] and Tok Pisin [tpi]; speakers are mostly older adults and concentrated in Central Province and Gulf Province.  120,000, all users. L1 users: Very few L1 speakers (1992 T. Dutton). L2 users: 120,000 (1989 J. Holm).

Spoken Languages.name: Petats
Spoken Languages.data: 10,000, all users. L1 users: 2,000 (1975 SIL). L2 users: 8,000 (Voegelin and Voegelin 1977).

Spoken Languages.name: Suau
Spoken Languages.data: A lingua franca around the south-eastern tip of Papua New Guinea.  20,800, all users. L1 users: 6,800 (Wurm and Hattori 1981). L2 users: 14,000. 680 monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Adzera
Spoken Languages.data: 30,000 (2000 census). A few monolinguals, among the youngest and oldest. Ethnic population: 31,000.

Spoken Languages.name: Dedua
Spoken Languages.data: 6,500 (2000 census), increasing. No monolinguals above age 20. Ethnic population: 8,910.

Spoken Languages.name: Kurti
Spoken Languages.data: 3,000 (2002 SIL). About 400 outside the language area.

Spoken Languages.name: Mutu
Spoken Languages.data: 3,500 (2007 SIL), increasing. Only older adults are monolingual. Ethnic population: 3,500.

Spoken Languages.name: Somba-Siawari
Spoken Languages.data: 10,000 (2000 census). 5,500 Somba, 4,500 Siawari. 1,000 monolinguals. Ethnic population: 11,000.

Spoken Languages.name: Waris
Spoken Languages.data: 2,500 in Papua New Guinea, increasing. Total users in all countries: 4,000.

Spoken Languages.name: Ambulas
Spoken Languages.data: 44,000 (1991 SIL). 27,000 in Wosera, 9,000 in Maprik, 8,000 in Wingei (1991 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Kerewo
Spoken Languages.data: 1,090 (2011 SIL). Population represents speakers living in their language area.

Spoken Languages.name: Ono
Spoken Languages.data: 11,000, all users. L1 users: 10,000 (2011 SIL), increasing. Population increase due to Bakesu Revival Church activity. L2 users: 1,000 (Voegelin and Voegelin 1977).

Spoken Languages.name: Umbu-Ungu
Spoken Languages.data: 34,200 (2000 census). 14,300 Andelale, 13,500 Kala, and 6,360 No-penge (2000 census).

Spoken Languages.name: Yagwoia
Spoken Languages.data: 10,000 (2005 R. Westerveld). 1,500 Iwalaqamalje, 1,500 Gwase, 7,000 Hiqwaye, Hiqwase, Yeqwangilje.

Spoken Languages.name: Zia
Spoken Languages.data: 4,500 (2000 SIL). 3,000 Zia (1991 SIL), 940 Mawae dialect. Ethnic population: 4,550.

Spoken Languages.name: Baruga
Spoken Languages.data: 2,230 (2003 SIL), increasing. 800 Tafota, 990 Bareji, 440 Mado. 200 monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Kiwai, Southern
Spoken Languages.data: 9,700 (Wurm 1975). 3,800 in Coast, 1,000 in Daru, 4,500 in Island Kiwai, 400 in Doumori. Several sources estimate current population now in excess of 20,000 (2011 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Korafe-Yegha
Spoken Languages.data: 3,630 (2003 SIL). A very few old women are monolingual.

Spoken Languages.name: Mussau-Emira
Spoken Languages.data: 6,000 (2015 SIL), increasing. Ethnic population: 6,000 (2015 SIL). Includes 3,500 in the traditional area (2015 J. Brownie).

Spoken Languages.name: Nali
Spoken Languages.data: 2,900 (2000 census). 200 Okro (2000 D. Tryon). Ethnic population: 4,500. In Okro.

Spoken Languages.name: Ninggerum
Spoken Languages.data: 5,150 in Papua New Guinea (2000 census). 2,060 monolinguals. Total users in all countries: 6,150.

Spoken Languages.name: Saliba
Spoken Languages.data: 2,500 (2007 SIL), increasing. 1,000 monolinguals. Young children, elderly.

Spoken Languages.name: Tabo
Spoken Languages.data: 3,000 (2002 SIL). Population split equally between dialects.

Spoken Languages.name: Timbe
Spoken Languages.data: 11,000 (1991 SIL). 660 monolinguals. Women and older men.

Spoken Languages.name: Yele
Spoken Languages.data: 3,750 (1998 Rossel Health Centres). 400 monolinguals. Ethnic population: 3,750 (1998).

Spoken Languages.name: Arawum
Spoken Languages.data: 320 (2016 J. Claussen). Ethnic population: 320 (2016 J. Claussen).

Spoken Languages.name: Dubuporo
Spoken Languages.data: 910 (2016 J. Claussen). Ethnic population: 910 (2016 J. Claussen).

Spoken Languages.name: Gamane
Spoken Languages.data: 150 (2016 J. Claussen). Ethnic population: 150 (2016 J. Claussen).

Spoken Languages.name: Kayan
Spoken Languages.data: 780, all users. L1 users: 740 (2013 PBT). L2 users: 40 (2013 PBT). Ethnic population: 790 (2013 PBT).

Spoken Languages.name: Maia
Spoken Languages.data: 4,500 (2007 SIL). 3,510 in main dialect, 990 in southern dialect (2017 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Mouwase
Spoken Languages.data: 450 (2011 SIL). Speakers of other languages live at some of the Mouwase villages, especially Omati, and this may have skewed population figures. Speakers are widely scattered in bush villages, hamlets and squatter settlements.

Spoken Languages.name: Nomane
Spoken Languages.data: 6,700 (2000 census). 3,140 Kewo-Meba, 2,290 Meine, 1,250 Siarha, and 20 Gomla (all men 35 and older).

Spoken Languages.name: Pano
Spoken Languages.data: 1,180 (2000 census). Including 433 in Singorokai Ward, 461 in Malasanga Ward and 279 in Kiari Ward.

Spoken Languages.name: Papua New Guinean Sign Language
Spoken Languages.data: Recognized language (2015, Decision No. 100/2015, Directive No. 8), National Executive Council (NEC) endorsement of the National Policy on disability 2015 - 2016 (7 May 2015).  30,000 (2015 N. Simonsson Juhonewe).

Spoken Languages.name: Tapei
Spoken Languages.data: 250 (Kassell et al 2017). Ethnic population: 250 (Kassell et al 2017).

Spoken Languages.name: Wagama
Spoken Languages.data: 600 (2017 SIL). No monolinguals (2017 SIL). Ethnic population: 1,000 (2017 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Manem
Spoken Languages.data: 500 in Papua New Guinea (1993 SIL). Total users in all countries: 900.

Spoken Languages.name: Sowanda
Spoken Languages.data: 970 in Papua New Guinea (2000 census). Total users in all countries: 1,180.

Spoken Languages.name: Bosmun
Spoken Languages.data: 1,725, all users. L1 users: 1,700 (2013 PBT). L2 users: 25 (2013 PBT). 260 monolinguals. Ethnic population: 1,800 (2013 PBT).

Spoken Languages.name: Duwet
Spoken Languages.data: 400 (2011 SIL), increasing. No monolinguals. Ethnic population: 450.

Spoken Languages.name: Eitiep
Spoken Languages.data: 500 (2003 SIL), decreasing. No monolinguals. Ethnic population: 500 (2000 census).

Spoken Languages.name: Nafi
Spoken Languages.data: 160 (Holzknecht 1988). May be less than 100 speakers (Wurm 2007). Ethnic population: 540 (2000 census).

Spoken Languages.name: One, Molmo
Spoken Languages.data: 700, all users. L1 users: 500 (2000 M. Crowther). L2 users: 200.

Spoken Languages.name: Onobasulu
Spoken Languages.data: 1,200, all users. L1 users: 1,000 (2010 SIL). L2 users: 200. 500 monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Urat
Spoken Languages.data: 6,280 (2003 SIL), decreasing. 2,480 in Wasep Ngau, 2,060 in Wusyep Yihre, 1,210 in Wasep Yam, and 550 in Wusyep Tep.

Spoken Languages.name: Sissano
Spoken Languages.data: 300 (Wurm 2000). In 1990, 4,780 speakers were reported and language use was vigorous. The 1998 tsunami almost completely annihilated the population. Number of surviving speakers unlikely to exceed a few hundred (Wurm 2007).

Spoken Languages.name: Kombio
Spoken Languages.data: 2,970 (2003 SIL), decreasing. Small groups in West New Britain, Vanimo and Lae areas; a few elsewhere. About 2,400 live in Kombio area. Very few monolinguals.

Spoken Languages.name: Matukar
Spoken Languages.data: 160 (Anderson et al 2015). Ethnic population: 700 (Anderson et al 2015).

Spoken Languages.name: Minidien
Spoken Languages.data: 100 (2004 SIL). No monolinguals. Ethnic population: 1,190 (2000 census).

Spoken Languages.name: Unserdeutsch
Spoken Languages.data: 10 in Papua New Guinea (2016 P. Maitz). Total users in all countries: 110.

Spoken Languages.name: Turumsa
Spoken Languages.data: 5 (2002 SIL), decreasing. Possibly no remaining speakers (2011).

Spoken Languages.name: Makolkol
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. 7 speakers reported in 1988. Some speakers may still be alive (Arlo 2016). Ethnic population: 5 (Arlo 2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Aribwatsa
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last speaker died in 1997 (Wurm 2007).

Spoken Languages.name: Bina
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Extinct by late 20th century.

Spoken Languages.name: Guramalum
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last known speaker survived into the early 1990s (1987 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Kaniet
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last known speaker died by 1950.

Spoken Languages.name: Karami
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker survived into the 1950s (Wurm 2007).

Spoken Languages.name: Laua
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last known speakers survived into the 1990s (1987 SIL).

Spoken Languages.name: Mulaha
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last known speaker survived into the 1950s (Wurm 2007).

Spoken Languages.name: Ouma
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last known speaker survived into the late 1980s (Wurm and Hattori 1981).

Spoken Languages.name: Sene
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last known speakers likely survived into the 1980s.

Spoken Languages.name: Uruava
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last known speaker survived into the 1980s.

Spoken Languages.name: Yoba
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. The last speaker probably survived into the 1980s (Dutton 1976).
