Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for United Kingdom is 13. All are living languages. Of these, 11 are indigenous and 2 are non-indigenous. Furthermore, 3 are institutional, 2 are developing, 3 are vigorous, 2 are in trouble, and 3 are dying.

Spoken Languages.name: English
Spoken Languages.data: De facto national language.  58,100,000 in United Kingdom, all users. L1 users: 56,600,000 in United Kingdom (2011 census). England and Wales 49,800,000, Scotland 5,118,000, Northern Ireland 1,681,000. L2 users: 1,500,000 (Crystal 2003a). Total users in all countries: 1,132,366,680 (as L1: 379,007,140; as L2: 753,359,540).

Spoken Languages.name: Scottish Gaelic
Spoken Languages.data: Statutory provincial language in Scotland (2005, Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act).  57,400 in United Kingdom (2011 census). Over 87,000 people with any Gaelic language skills (2011 census). Total users in all countries: 60,130.

Spoken Languages.name: Welsh
Spoken Languages.data: Statutory provincial language in Wales (1993, Welsh Language Act, C 38).  562,000 in United Kingdom (2011 census), decreasing. 32,700 monolinguals (1971 census). Total users in all countries: 573,050.

Spoken Languages.name: British Sign Language
Spoken Languages.data: 327,000, all users. L1 users: 77,000 (2014 EUD). L2 users: 250,000 (2013 K. Crombie Smith).

Spoken Languages.name: Scots
Spoken Languages.data: 1,589,200 in United Kingdom, all users. L1 users: 89,200 in United Kingdom (2011 census). 55,800 in Scotland, 33,400 in Northern Ireland. L2 users: 1,500,000 (2001 census). Total users in all countries: 1,599,200 (as L1: 99,200; as L2: 1,500,000).

Spoken Languages.name: Angloromani
Spoken Languages.data: 90,000 in United Kingdom (Hancock 1990b). Total users in all countries: 99,200.

Spoken Languages.name: Irish Sign Language
Spoken Languages.data: 1,500 in United Kingdom (Parks and Parks 2012). 4,500 Deaf signers (2019 EUD).

Spoken Languages.name: Shelta
Spoken Languages.data: 16,700 in United Kingdom (2008 A. Redmond). 15,000 in England and Scotland, 1,710 in Northern Ireland (2008 A. Redmond).

Spoken Languages.name: Irish
Spoken Languages.data: 5,730 in United Kingdom (2011 census). England and Wales 1,560, Northern Ireland 4,170. Widely used as L2 in all parts of Northern Ireland.

Spoken Languages.name: Cornish
Spoken Languages.data: 600, all users. L1 users: No known L1 speakers, but emerging L2 speakers. The identity of the last speaker is hotly debated by scholars. Some sources say the last L1 speaker was Dorothy ‘Dolly’ Pentreath, who died in 1777. L2 users: 600 (2011 census). Ethnic population: 73,200 (2011 census).

Spoken Languages.name: Romani, Welsh
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Last speaker, Manfri Wood, died in 1968.

Spoken Languages.name: Polari
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: No ethnic community.

Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for Iran is 80. Of these, 79 are living and 1 is extinct. Of the living languages, 65 are indigenous and 14 are non-indigenous. Furthermore, 6 are institutional, 10 are developing, 22 are vigorous, 32 are in trouble, and 9 are dying.

Spoken Languages.name: Persian, Iranian
Spoken Languages.data: Statutory national language (1979, Constitution, Article 15).  49,600,000 in Iran (2016), increasing. 800,000 Eastern Farsi in Khorasan speak dialects which are transitional with Iranian Persian. Total users in all countries: 52,782,160.

Spoken Languages.name: Azerbaijani, South
Spoken Languages.data: 10,900,000 in Iran (2016). Ethnic population: 15,900,000 (2014 J. Leclerc). Total users in all countries: 13,813,750.

Spoken Languages.name: Kurdish, Central
Spoken Languages.data: De facto provincial working language in northwest.  527,000 in Iran (2014 J. Leclerc). All Kurdish in Iran: 5,590,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Arabic, Standard
Spoken Languages.data: Recognized language (1979, Constitution, Article 16), used in education.  1,320,000 in Iran (2015 SIL), all users.

Spoken Languages.name: Balochi, Southern
Spoken Languages.data: 474,000 in Iran (2014 J. Leclerc). All Balochi in Iran: 1,920,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Balochi, Western
Spoken Languages.data: 704,000 in Iran (2014 J. Leclerc). All Balochi in Iran: 1,920,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Mazandarani
Spoken Languages.data: 2,340,000 (2016), decreasing. Some monolinguals in rural areas.

Spoken Languages.name: Kurdish, Northern
Spoken Languages.data: 465,000 in Iran (2014 J. Leclerc). All Kurdish in Iran: 5,590,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Pashto, Southern
Spoken Languages.data: 113,000 in Iran (1993). Population does not include refugees.

Spoken Languages.name: Hazaragi
Spoken Languages.data: 368,000 in Iran (2014 J. Leclerc). Population increased significantly due to influx of Hazaragi-speaking refugees from Afghanistan.

Spoken Languages.name: Kurdish, Southern
Spoken Languages.data: 3,000,000 in Iran (Fattah 2000). All Kurdish in Iran: 5,590,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Assyrian Neo-Aramaic
Spoken Languages.data: 15,000 in Iran (1994). Ethnic population: 103,000 (2014 J. Leclerc).

Spoken Languages.name: Laraki
Spoken Languages.data: 700 in Iran, all users. L1 users: 670 in Iran (Anonby and Yousefian 2011). L2 users: 30 (Anonby and Yousefian 2011). 70 monolinguals (Anonby and Yousefian 2011).

Spoken Languages.name: Gurani
Spoken Languages.data: 180,000 in Iran (Paul 2007). Population provisionally estimated to be two-thirds of the 300,000 speakers in Iran and Iraq (2007 L. Paul). Total users in all countries: 300,000.

Spoken Languages.name: Avestan
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: No ethnic community.

Spoken Languages.name: Mandaic, Classical
Spoken Languages.data: No known L1 speakers in Iran. Ethnic population: No ethnic community. Total users in all countries: none known.

Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for Bhutan is 23. All are living languages. Of these, 21 are indigenous and 2 are non-indigenous. Furthermore, 3 are institutional, 1 is developing, 4 are vigorous, and 15 are in trouble.

Spoken Languages.name: Dzongkha

Spoken Languages.data: Statutory national language (2001, Constitution, Article 1).  4,297,000 in Senegal, all users. L1 users: 47,000 in Senegal (2015 J. Leclerc). L2 users: 4,250,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Crioulo, Upper Guinea
Spoken Languages.data: Used as an LWC from the Lower Casamance of Senegal to the north of Guinea-Bissau. People who traveled from Guinea-Bissau as a Portuguese-based country to the Casamance of southern Senegal led to the development as an LWC. It is used in churches (interpretation and singing) and in the market, business and radio.  30,000 in Senegal, all users. L1 users: 10,000 in Senegal (Biagui and Quint 2013). L2 users: 20,000 (Biagui and Quint 2013).

Data.Language Counts: The number of individual languages listed for Angola is 47. Of these, 46 are living and 1 is extinct. Of the living languages, 41 are indigenous and 5 are non-indigenous. Furthermore, 6 are institutional, 16 are developing, 19 are vigorous, and 5 are in trouble.

Spoken Languages.name: Portuguese
Spoken Languages.data: Statutory national language (2010, Constitution, Article 19(1)).  15,470,000 in Angola, all users. L1 users: 10,300,000 in Angola (2016). Includes 60,000 foreign L1 users. In cities, Portuguese increasingly L1 of younger generation. 60% of Angolans use Portuguese, 40% as L1. High level of urbanization due to civil war led to increased use. L2 users: 5,170,000 (2016).

Spoken Languages.name: Oshiwambo
Spoken Languages.data: De facto language of national identity. Its use as an LWC has its origin in its status as the language of the powerful Kwanyama kingdom, influential in what is now southern Angola and northern Namibia throughout the colonial period up to the year 1917. Used in the eastern half of Kunene Province in church, market, business, and media domains.  461,000 in Angola, all users. L1 users: 421,000 in Angola (Johnstone 1993). L2 users: 40,000 (2013 SIL). Total users in all countries: 1,481,000 (as L1: 1,441,000; as L2: 40,000).

Spoken Languages.name: Equatorial Guinean Pidgin
Spoken Languages.data: Used as LWC across Bioko island, including the capital city of Malabo, in all domains except education and government.  76,000, all users. L1 users: 6,000 (2011 S. Smith), increasing. L2 users: 70,000 (2011 S. Smith). Very few monolinguals. Ethnic population: 6,000.

Spoken Languages.name: Fang
Spoken Languages.data: De facto language of national identity. Used as LWC in continental Equatorial Guinea (the area previously known as Rio Muni). Used in church, market, business, media, and music. It became a LWC by virtue of its dominant status as mother tongue of 85% of the country’s population.  624,000 in Equatorial Guinea, all users. L1 users: 589,000 in Equatorial Guinea (2013 S. Smith), increasing. L2 users: 35,000 (2013 S. Smith). Total users in all countries: 1,106,100 (as L1: 1,071,100; as L2: 35,000).

Data.Population: 1,171,000 in Ireland, all users. L1 users: 141,000 in Ireland . L2 users: 1,030,000 . Total users in all countries: 1,200,300 .
Data.Location: Cork, Donegal, Galway, Kerry, part of Mayo, Meath, and Waterford counties. Western isles northwest and southwest coasts.
Data.Typology: VSO; prepositions; noun head initial; gender ; definite article; case-marking ; verb affixes mark person, number; tense and aspect; comparatives; 32 consonants, 11 vowels, 4 diphthongs; non-tonal; stress on first syllable; initial consonant mutation.
Data.Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A number of children learn the language but the number is decreasing . Also use English  .
Data.Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Irish
Data.Writing: Latin script . Latin script, Gaelic variant . Ogham script , no longer in use.
Data.Other Comments: Taught as an official language in schools and encouraged by the government.

Data.Location: Wyoming: Wind River Reservation; also associated with Cheyenne  in central Oklahoma.
Data.Language Status: 8a . Language of registered tribe: Arapaho Tribe of the Wind River Reservation , Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes , Shoshone Tribe of the Wind River Reservation.
Data.Language Use: No L1 speakers in Oklahoma . Older adults only.
Data.Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1903. Bilingual education efforts begun on Wind River Reservation in the 1980s. Arapaho Language Lodge established in 1993, a successful immersion program .
Data.Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Arapaho

Data.Alternate Names: Ikomagi, Jinca, Shinkan, Shinkan Complex, Sinca, Szinca, Xincan, Xinka, “Popoloco”

Data.Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Xinca

Data.Population: 612,000,000 in India, all users. L1 users: 339,000,000 in India . L2 users: 273,000,000 . Total users in all countries: 615,475,540 .
Data.Location: Widespread in north India: northern Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Punjab, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, and Uttarakhand states; Delhi.
Data.Language Status: 1 . Statutory national language , also statutory provincial language in Bihar State and 12 other jurisdictions.
Data.Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Western Hindi, Hindustani
Data.Dialects: Khari Boli . Formal vocabulary borrowed from Sanskrit, de-Persianized, de-Arabicized. Literary Hindi, or Hindi-Urdu, has 4 varieties: Hindi ; Urdu ; Dakhini; Rekhta. Hindustani, though not listed separately in India, refers here to the unofficial lingua franca of northwest India. Has a lexical mixture in varying proportions of Hindi  and Urdu .
Data.Typology: SOV; postpositions; noun head final; content q-word in situ; gender ; no articles; clause constituents partially indicated by case-marking , postpositions, and word order; verbal affixation marks person, number, gender, and honorificity of subject; split ergativity; both tense and aspect; passives and voice; causatives; non-tonal; 30 consonants, 10 vowels, 2 diphthongs; stress linked to syllable weight.
Data.Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Hindi
Data.Writing: Braille script . Devanagari script , primary usage. Newa script , no longer in use, historic usage.
Data.Other Comments: Hindi, Hindustani, Urdu could be considered co-dialects, but have important sociolinguistic differences. Hindu.

Data.Location: Boucle du Mouhoun region: small areas in Bale province; Hauts-Bassins region: Houet province; Sud-Ouest region: Bougouriba province, Dolo, near Diébougou.
